channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Peacekeeping in the Central African Republic Survives Washington’s Ax
item.description: The United Nations Security Council renewed the mandate of its peacekeeping mission in the Central African Republic on Thursday, amid strong opposition from the United States. The mission will continue to protect civilians and support the fragile peace process of the country as it faces crucial national elections in the next year while agreeing to ... Read more

item.title: Innovation in action: Scaling climate solutions from the ground up
item.description: CropLife International’s Laurie Goodwin joins Devex Executive Editor Kate Warren for a special edition podcast about how innovation and open trade can work together to build climate-resilient food systems.

item.title: Forcefully Deported Afghan Women Return to a Life of Fear and Anxiety
item.description: The author is an Afghanistan-based female journalist, trained with Finnish support before the Taliban take-over. Her identity is withheld for security reasons

item.title: US has begun bilateral health negotiations with 16 African nations
item.description: This is part of the State Department’s new strategy around global health — engaging directly with countries as opposed to through implementing partners.

item.title: Brazil, WHO launch pioneering climate adaptation road map for health
item.description: As COP30 observed Health Day on Thursday, world leaders came together to witness the launch of the Belém Health Action Plan for the adaptation of climate change to the health sector.

item.title: COP30 reporters’ notebook: Day 4
item.description: On the ground at the 30th United Nations Climate Change Conference, Devex reporters deliver the latest updates.

item.title: We’re All in the Same Storm, Different Boats, Says Young Activist With Disability
item.description: At the UN Climate Conference venue in Belém, young activist João Vitor da Costa da Silva is trying to make his case heard by negotiators. The 16-year-old Da Silva has a specific request for the parties: the needs of young people with disabilities should be addressed through the lens of climate justice. Belém native Da […]

item.title: Here's what CIFF says it will do more, and less of
item.description: One of the foundation's executives says CIFF remains committed to SRHR and is keen to expand its partnerships. But there are some things it is moving away from.

item.title: Brazil is Breathing Life into Climate Commitments—Human Rights Lawyer
item.description: Climate change crisis offers us a real chance to bring a new vision, one that's rooted in fairness, dignity and harmony with nature. The global community here has the ability and opportunity to balance people, profit, and planet in a way that has not been achieved in the past. —Binaifer Nowrojee, human rights lawyer and president of the Open Society Foundations (OSF)

item.title: Devex CheckUp: What to expect when you’re expecting new global health agreements
item.description: A look at the template for bilateral health deals between the U.S. and partner governments. Plus, Stop TB Partnership explores other funding mechanisms, and a new malaria treatment shows promise in blocking transmission.

item.title: How to use AI in your job search and what mistakes to avoid
item.description: Luan Prinsloo, global talent acquisition manager at World Vision, shares how development job seekers can use artificial intelligence to support their job search and how over-reliance on these tools can harm a candidate's chances.

item.title: What you can expect to earn from climate jobs
item.description: With COP30 ongoing this week, here is everything you need to know about salary information for climate-focused jobs.

item.title: Devex Newswire: Brazil’s $125B forest fund branches out with banks
item.description: At COP30, EBRD and AIIB consider investing in the Tropical Forest Forever Facility; the foundation betting big on climate adaptation; and what’s in the stopgap U.S. funding bill for development work.

item.title: Poor Countries Welcome Loss and Damage Fund’s Call for Requests, Warn It Falls Short of Needs
item.description: Our countries did not light this fire—but we are burning in its heat. And the smoke does not stop at our borders. —Evans Njewa, Least Developed Countries Group chair, when talking about the importance of the Loss and Damage Fund for LDCs

item.title: Ethiopia: UN supports response to potentially deadly virus outbreak
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) is supporting Ethiopia as the country faces a suspected viral haemorraghic fever outbreak in the south, the UN agency said on Thursday.

item.title: Gaza: War has made children violent, sad and bereft
item.description: More than nine in 10 children in Gaza are displaying signs of aggressive behaviour linked to more than two years of war between Hamas and Israel, welfare agencies have reported.

item.title: Protecting lives in a warming world: Health takes centre stage at COP30
item.description: Hailed by Brazil as “a crucial moment to demonstrate the strength of the health sector in global climate action,” a blueprint for global health systems to adapt to rising temperatures and extreme weather has been launched at the COP30 UN climate conference.

item.title: Families in Sudan ‘running out of time’ as hunger spreads
item.description: More than 21 million people in Sudan, 45 per cent of the population, are not getting enough to eat as the war between rival militaries continues, according to the World Food Programme (WFP).

item.title: Ending UNWRA services would imperil political way forward: Lazzarini
item.description: Lack of sufficient funds is jeopardizing the ability of the UN relief agency for Palestine refugees (UNRWA) to operate, the head of the agency said on Thursday.

item.title: From Haiti to Ethiopia: voices of climate displacement at COP30
item.description: Floods, heatwaves, droughts and storms are forcing millions from their homes every year. Most never cross a border; they remain internally displaced yet uprooted all the same. But experts warn that in the not-so-distant future, entire nations could disappear beneath rising seas or become uninhabitable through drought.

item.title: World News in Brief: Typhoon generation, disability rights in Myanmar, new refugee-led climate fund
item.description: The strongest typhoon to make landfall this year in the Philippines has impacted a staggering 1.7 million children – and more than five million people overall.

item.title: Philanthropies commit $300M for climate-health solutions at COP30
item.description: A new coalition of 35 funders is backing efforts to scale solutions on extreme heat, air pollution, and climate-driven disease — and strengthen climate-resilient health systems.

item.title: Hot potato: How a new blight-resistant variety is boosting food security
item.description: As climate change drives a devastating plant disease into new regions, a new potato variety developed in Peru gives farmers an option that reduces losses and cuts costs.

item.title: International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, 2025
item.description: Violence against women is a human rights emergency in every country. One in three women worldwide experience physical and/or sexual violence in their lifetime. Most survivors are harmed by an intimate partner. Every ten minutes, a woman or girl is killed by a partner or family member. Around sixty percent of female homicides are […]

item.title: Public Health Besieged by Industry Interference
item.description: The 183 Parties to the global health treaty, WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (FCTC) will convene in Geneva from 17 – 22 November with one objective – to strengthen their efforts to arrest the No.1 preventable cause of disease and 7 million deaths annually – tobacco use. The WHO FCTC is unique in that […]

item.title: Matthew Crentsil: A lone African seeks top UN refugee job
item.description: Europe retreats on migration, but seeks to preserve a near monopoly over the U.N. high commissioner for refugees post.
